sentence: U.S. stocks were mostly lower Tuesday following a freefall for Chinese stocks overnight and disappointing quarterly results this morning by the world's largest retailer working to upstage more upbeat data for the U.S. housing market.
Minutes from last month's Federal Open Market Committee due out tomorrow also were adding to the defensive tone, with investors largely expecting the Fed to take on a slightly less dovish bias.
Dow component Walmart ( WMT ) said that recent employee wage increases and a stronger dollar caused Q2 earnings to shrink 15% compared with year-ago levels.
It also cut its Q3 and FY15 profit outlooks, driving shares of the mega-retailer to a 19-month low.
The Walmart results eclipsed positive results from Home Depot ( HD ), another Dow component company, as well as by TJX Companies ( TJX ) and Dick's Sporting Goods ( DKS ).
Like the mostly retail positive earnings, upbeat housing market data today failed to impress Wall Street.
Housing starts rose 0.2% to a seasonally-adjusted annual rate of 1.206 million homes, beating expert opinion looking an annualized pace of 1.180 million new starts.
June activity also were revised upward to 1.204 million from the 1.174 million annual pace initially reported.

But while housing starts rose to a nearly eight-year high last month, the Commerce Department also reported the number of new building permits declined 16.3% from year-ago levels to an annualized pace of 1.119 million.
Over the past 3 months, however, housing permits were being pulled at a 1.337 million annualized pace, up from the 1.028 million rate reported in March.
European equities struggled to climb out from negative ground, but couldn't overcome the impact of the 6.2% nosedive by Chinese equities overnight.
UK inflation data reported today was seen as giving the Bank of England breathing room to begin raising interest rates later this year or early in 2015.
Crude oil was up 35 cents to $42.22 per barrel.
Natural gas was down 3 cents to $2.74 per 1 million BTU.
Gold was down $2.40 to $1,116.00 per ounce, while silver was down 52 cents to $14.78 per ounce.
Copper was down 4 cents to $2.28 per pound.
Among energy ETFs, the United States Oil Fund was up 0.72% to $14.00 with the United States Natural Gas Fund was down 0.99% to $12.99.
Among precious-metal funds, the Market Vectors Gold Miners ETF was down 1.06% to 14.88 while SPDR Gold Shares were down 0.12% to $107.00.
The iShares Silver Trust was down 3.21% to $14.16.

Here's where the U.S. markets stood at mid-day:
